conclusion: Determine the angle between the velocity vector of the slider at point B and the horizontal direction when it lands at point C.
Calculate the velocity v_B at point B using the energy conservation principle.
Potential energy stored in the compressed spring is converted into kinetic energy of the slider.
Mass of the slider, m = 2 kg.
Initial potential energy of the spring, U = 1/2 k x^2.
Final kinetic energy of the slider, K = 1/2 m v_B^2.
Since the initial potential energy is equal to the kinetic energy, k x^2 = m v_B^2.
v_B = sqrt(k x^2 / m).
Horizontal distance x_{BC} = 0.9 m.
This distance is the horizontal component of the slider's trajectory.
Height of the arc is R = 0.4 m, and angle θ = 37°.
Vertical distance y_C = h - R(1 + cos θ).
Time of flight t can be found by considering the vertical motion of the slider.
Vertical displacement y_C is given by y_C = v_{By} t - 1/2 g t^2.
v_{By} is the vertical component of the velocity at point B.
Angle α between the velocity vector at point C and the horizontal direction can be determined using the components of the velocity vector.
Horizontal component of the velocity remains constant during the flight: v_{Cx} = v_B.
Vertical component of the velocity at point C is v_{Cy} = v_{By} - gt.
tan α = v_{Cy} / v_{Cx}.
Vertical component of the velocity at point B can be found using the initial conditions: v_{By} = v_B sin θ.
Substitute v_B = sqrt(k x^2 / m) and solve for α.
